captions.text: Good morning John!

So a little while ago, I went on Google, and
I was going to ask the question, "What is

the difference between something and something?".
But I didn't get that far because I noticed

how interesting all the questions other people
were asking were.

So having forgotten completely what I was
going to ask Google, instead, today I'm just

going to answer all of the questions other
people were asking for every letter of the
alphabet. Starting with: A.

Crows and ravens are two completely different
species. If there's a bunch of them and they're

acting and sounding pretty annoying, those
are crows. If there's one or two of them,

and you think, "Is that a cat, because it's
huge," that's a raven.

Baking soda is the chemical sodium bicarbonate.
It produces carbon dioxide when mixed with

an acid, and that carbon dioxide fluffs up
baked goods. Baking powder is baking soda

with the acid already mixed in, so all you
have to do is add water.

In the US, a college is a school that teaches
only the years directly after secondary education.

A university has some graduate school components.
To make things extra confusing, both colleges
and universities can contain other colleges.

Dinner vs. supper is a really interesting
linguistic thing that happened. Apparently,
supper means a different thing to EVERYONE.

English people and things are from England,
which is a country inside the country of the

United Kingdom. British people and things
technically are anything from the United Kingdom,

so Northern Irish people, Welsh people, Scottish
people: all British - though they probably
don't want to be called that.

Hair and fur are, scientifically, the exact
same thing.

Hulu Plus costs more, and you can watch it
on your TV or your mobile device. There's
also very slightly more content on Hulu Plus.

The 5C is the, kind of, value edition of the
iPhone. The camera and the processor and the
design are all a little bit less fancy.

Jelly is jellied juice and jam is jellied
fruit pulp, so jam is a little bit softer.

As with anything in linguistics, this is surprisingly
complicated, but both kun and san are Japanese

honorific suffixes. They're added to the end
of names to show respect. San is used between

equals, while kun is used in reference to
someone junior to you, generally a male person.

LCD is the kind of display technology, LED
is the kind of back-lighting the TV has. They

have nothing to do with each other, and these
days, most TVs are LCD displays back-lit by
LED.

I mean, biologically, there's very little
difference between you and me. Humans are
all very, very similar to each other.

I have no idea what NAS and SAN are. I looked
it up, and it's something to do with IT infrastructure,
and sorry, out of my depth there.

Subjective statements are based in opinion;
objective statements are based in fact.

This first one makes no sense, so I'm gonna
skip it.

Prisons are where you go when you've been
convicted of a crime and sentenced to serve

time. Jails are where you go when you've just
been detained or have been arrested and are

awaiting trial. You can also end up in a jail
if you've been convicted but your sentence
isn't very long.

Both full and quick formats will wipe all
the data off your hard drive, but only the

full format will rebuild the file structures
that the drive itself uses to store the files
and scan for bad sectors on the drive.

Both Rangers and Green Berets are special
operations forces in the Army. Any recruit

can apply to be a Ranger, but only soldiers
who have been in the army for at least three

years can apply to be a Green Beret. Green
Berets must also speak at least two languages.

The duties performed by both groups, though,
are similar.

Scotch is a type of whiskey. It's Scotch,
meaning that it's made in Scotland.

"Too" either means "excessively" or "also."
"To" is just for all the other times, unless
you mean "two."

As far as I can tell, Uber and Lyft are pretty
much the same thing. They're both new-fangled

ways to get taxis, and people seem surprisingly
excited about both considering that taxis
will be mostly driven by robots in ten years.

Green cards give you the right to permanently
live and work in the US, while visas only
temporarily give you that right.

Green and white asparagus are the same plant,
but white asparagus has dirt piled on top

of it while it's growing, so that it's never
exposed to light. Under all that dirt, it

doesn't produce chlorophyll, and it doesn't
need the structures necessary to stand up

on its own, so it's milder in flavor and softer
in texture.

x64 is the 64-bit CPU architecture for Windows
7 that works on newer machines, while x86
is the older 32-bit design.
Green and yellow zucchini are different colors.
And finally,
A zucchini is a squash!

John, I hope this video was educational for
you and for everybody else, and I'll see you
on Tuesday.

I made this script publicly available before
I made this video, as part of the Nerdfighter

Online Video Workshop, so people have already
uploaded their versions of this video on their

channels before I did, which is weird. So
far, the NOVW is, just, very cool. Thanks

to everyone who's been doing performances
and edits and script-writing, and especially

to people who have been constructively critiquing
those performances and edits and scripts.

If you'd like to learn more about the NOVW,
there's a link in the description.

comments.author: jim bob

comments.text:
さん - san is actually closer to a catch all honorific in American context. 
It IS what you use in polite conversation when speaking formally to people, 
but considering we Americans don't tend to call our classmates, coworkers, 
and people on the street default by their last name, it doesn't make much 
sense to us. If you have 2 third graders who are not that close called Mike 
Applebee and Drew Smith, they will call each other Mr. Applebee and Mr. 
Smith in the Japanese system. "First" (really second) names in Japan are to 
Japanese people what nicknames are to us. We are completely ok calling John 
Doe John to his face even though we aren't that close, unless it's strictly 
businessman-client or doctor patient or something VERY formal. You can use 
san to speak with superiors (meiue). The caveat is that because they are 
meiue, they don't HAVE to speak formally or respectfully to you, but they 
choose to because they are not fartbags.

くん - kun on the other hand is...actually very rarely used when compared to 
-san. In fact, it's less of a honorific to denote closeness and more of an 
honorific to make the name diminutive, like little boys. It'd be the 
equivalent of saying "Little Johnny". Just Johnny would actually be better 
translated simply as the name. See, if you are at the point where kun would 
not be offensive, you are close enough to the person that just using their 
name should be ok (and usually preferred).

The female equivalent ちゃん chan is TECHNICALLY identical in function to kun 
IN THEORY. In practice, it's a whole different thing altogether in usage.

The honorifics that would be used specifically to denote superiority and 
respect are either niche e.g. senpai or anachronistic e.g. dono or just 
plain odd e.g. sama. Yes, fangirls raving about Sesshoumaru-sama~~ sounds 
just as weird in Japanese as it does in English. So san is pretty much the 
bread and butter for names. If you have no idea which honorific to use, san 
is your best bet in every situation no matter who you're talking to.

24% of expression of formality and respect is expressed through wordchoice 
(like in English). 1% is the above. The other 50% is the conjugation of 
verbs. You are reading that correctly. You conjugate all verbs based on 
formality. I am not kidding.﻿

comments.author: Xidnaf

comments.text:
NAS is a Network Attached Storage which is essentially just a box of hard 
drives which becomes a network share using different protocols to connect 
to the share depending on the OS that is connecting. 

SAN is Storage Area Network which is very similar to a NAS when looking at 
the actual devices but SAN's are not accessible from all devices on the 
network but instead are typically connected to server's using iSCSI and is 
used greatly when expanding the internal storage of a server without the 
need to change all the internal drives.  This is because all servers have 
RAID Arrays so if a physical drive was replaced for a bigger drive , 1 it 
is unlikely to work at all as all drive's in the array need to be identical 
and also if it did work the extra space would be ignored and the logical 
drive would be the same size. SAN's are much higher in performance so can 
be quite costly. ﻿

file system over a network.﻿

comments.author: Merlin Speaks

comments.text:
NAS - Network Attached Storage
SAN - Storage Area Network(s)

A NAS is a singular storage unit that can contain redundancy or not and is 
more likely used in a smaller network environment (such as a small business 
or home). It is typically connected to a network via an Ethernet Cable (or 
the plasticy jacketed cable with white rectangular ends that gives you 
Internet).

A SAN is a more complex storage unit that is used to a shared storage space 
that multiple devices utilize for varying purposes. These are a lot more 
complex and really had to explain in a short paragraph. SANs are big, 
expensive and intelligent pieces of hardware loaded up with hard disks that 
larger enterprises leverage for storage.

*crickets* I'll see myself out...﻿

comments.author: enCODed3

comments.text:
Preemptive disclaimer, I'm still a bit green in my corner of the sysad 
world, and I'm primarily exposed to the equipment and configurations that 
my comany uses, so this may certainly be incomplete, but here goes:

NAS (Network Attached Storage) and SAN (Storage Area Network) are both 
basically servers with lots of hard drive space that it shares with other 
computers on the network.

Generally speaking, SAN will present just chunks of harddrive, which the 
server utilizing it controls completely (it would recognize it basically as 
a regular harddrive), while NAS shares directories/folders that it 
otherwise manages itself.

Also, NAS operates over a standard copper network (messages sent 
electrically through wire), and SAN operates over a fiber optic network 
(light sent through cables made of glass fibers), which is quite a bit 
faster.﻿

comments.text:
-Kun is not used for people of lower level, it's used for people of the 
same level who you're close to OR for people of a lower level who you're 
close to (and children). -San is used for people of the same level or 
higher with almost everyone you meet when you become an adult (friends, 
friends of friends, aquaintances etc), and -sama is used for people who are 
much higher or customers. Children use -kun and -chan a lot, and while kun 
is for boys and chan is for girls, they CAN be used for the opposite gender 
rarely but the older you get the less you use them in general.﻿
